reviews.review_text: Like Metal Slug? Like gun customization? Like stabbing people with a fish?    I do.

I really wanted to like this game. This comes from the people who made Scott Pilgrim vs. The World: The Game, which I loved and looks like it plays like Contra or Metal Slug, which I also love. Well, the graphics are very aesthetically pleasing in animation and both character and background designs. There are actually a lot of really cool looking enemies. The music is quite well done too. The problem is the gameplay. While watching videos it looks as if the game does everything right but the problem is: the game just isn't that fun. The game wants to be an old school run and gun but there's a lot of backtracking (which is even more annoying since the enemies respawn) and you have to reload every five or so seconds if you are run and gunning. The idea to put in a reload system was dumb but they way they did it (a time sensitive system) was actually kind of cool. Though it getting annoying fast. I found myself avoiding enemies so I didn't have to reload and then was wondering why I was still playing this game after avoiding the main game mechanic (shooting).

it was fun at first, but it got really repetitive really fast. the music is really cool, it has a really deep crafting system in which you can customize each part of your gun, and the art is BEAUTIFUL. however, it just goes downhill from there. there's one or two maps that you play on for EVERY. SINGLE. MISSION. absolutely nothing is different; not the enemy placement, not the item placement, not the platforming, not the music, anything (unless it's a boss). i really, really wanted to enjoy this game, especially since i spent $45 on three copies of this game for me and my friends. but i just can't.

Playing Mercenary Kings this past week, since its official release, is the most fun I've had with any game in years. That's not to say I don't enjoy the other games I play and adore, but this just tickles a fancy like none other. The rewards offered through progression, the challenges when the enemies ramp up, or when a new boss is introduced - they make playing endlessly entertaining. Now, much of the criticism the receives is due to a popular idea that the game is similar to Metal Slug. I've personally never played it, shame on me and such, but if you're looking for that experience, then you ought to play Metal Slug. This isn't like another game I've played, while it shares elements with many, it's an entity of its own. For many reasons this will remain one of my top picks for this year, if not longer, and there's no reason not to play it. Oh, get a controller.  April 10th revisions:  Oh... yeah... I'll have to recall some of those statements. The multiplayer is pretty much dying since launch, and the game isn't really that entertaining once you get your best gun. That being said, I got 60 hours of playtime out of it at its $15 launch price, so I'll definitely still recommend it. I just don't know how often I'll go back to it anymore. Whether I return to actively playing M.K. is really going to depend on how the Devs treat the game - as a product that could still use some improvements / additions, or as a finished game. Kinda feels melancholy leaving it behind for now...

Mercenary Kings on the outside looks like a really fun game, it has the Metal Slug aesthetics and it also has a passionate and supporting fan base.  On that note I really did not enjoy the game and will be presenting the pros and cons in a list fashion.  Pros.    Amazing pixel art by Paul Robertson.    Lots of guns and gun combinations.    A very lenghty campaign.    Funny dialog.    Great music.   Cons.    Very tedious missions.    You have to grind missions over and over to get materials .    Bosses are bullet sponges and very unjustly so as a boss only has about 5-7 attacks each.    Areas in the late game are very tight and damages you for the slightest wrong move.    Most bonuses/ammo types requires you to grind making the game very lackluster and empty for people that don't like that.   Now althought this didn't really affect my enjoyment/disappointment with the game, the story was reminiscent of Cave Story down to an almost identical last boss.   All in all I probably would never replay this game again, as I did complete every mission the game offered.

Platformer-shooter version of Monster Hunter.  You probably won't enjoy this game if you hate the following : - Grinding - Boss that keep running away because **** you - Running in the same ****ing map over and over - Timed mission - Back to grinding - What the **** stop running away - NOT THIS MAP AGAIN NO - Grinding some more - STOP RUNNING AWAY I HAVE 2 MINUTES LEFT YOU ****  Yeah it's 80% Monster Hunter.

If you've ever enjoyed a single sidescrolling run and gun game in your life, get this without hesitation. This is probably better than most of them anyway. It scrolls sideways (and up an down too!) and you both run and gun in a very pleasant manner. Meanwhile your visual cortex is being stimulated by the gorgeously animated pixel art.   The one single negative thing I can think of is that you sometimes have to run back and forth across the level searching for whatever the mission objective happens to be. Hopefully this being the game's only fault in my mind will tell you something.

Have you ever wanted to build a gun out of a toilet, a skull, a cat, AND a rifle scope? Well, look no further! In Mercenary kings, you and some buddies can play this side-scroller cooperatively, collecting resources, completing objectives, upgrading your characters... and building guns! Lots and lots of guns. There is some re-use of environments, and some of the enemies can be a little cheap, but the humor, pixel art, and objectives will keep you hooked!

I thought it was like Metal Slug and bought it. It turns out to be Monster Hunter like.  -Missions have time limit. -Huge map, and you have to find where the target(boss, prisoner, item) is. -Slow paced action. Enemies takes several shots to kill. -Enemies respawn after you walk away, you may be killed by them wandering around. -Going through the map takes several minutes, if you missed something in the middle you may not have enough time to complete the mission. -The boss teleports between certain points, which could take you several minutes to travel. -The teleport happens every a few minutes, you get close to it, oh sorry too late, it's gone again. -And of course, collect meterials to upgrade equipments.  I like the pixel art, the music is decent. But gameplay ruins everything. Missions feel long and repetitive as hell.

I haven't delved too much into this game but from what I've played I really like the old school side scrolling 2d aspect to this game. I think the most common description of this game would be something along the lines of Metal Slug x Borderlands. Where the gameplay is obviously like Metal Slug but the be all end all is to upgrade your weapons, armor and mods through pickups. I think at most that's where this game kinda diverts from the two games mentioned and probably falls closer to the gathering games found in MInecraft or Terraria. There is no leveling method from what I've seen and the only way to increase your health and weaponry is by increasing your money by doing missions and picking up material drops found during those missions. At first, the game may seem difficult like most shooters will but once you get a decent upgrade going the game will start feeling like classic shooters from days past. I think what sold me on this game was when I was rolling with another player online (4 player co-op) and she was carrying around the spread gun. That's right a spread gun from Contra!

A 'monster hunter'-like platformer.  Pros Great character and level design Great music Great pixel animations Tons of gun parts and knives for crafting Interesting boss fights Has a story and an ending  Cons Matchmaking for public coop is random (You cant choose whom you want to join) Feeling of 'heaviness' when controlling character. Will get used to it after a while.  Recommended if you like mission-based game and have no problem farming materials over and over again to craft bettter weapons.

Modernized Metal Slug with style.  There are a lot of throwback games nowadays, but this one just brings so much to the table that it’s worth checking out. Not many games have made use of the delicate pixel art that Metal Slug introduced us to. Why you might say? I think it’s because it requires a lot of work and the style has a lot of detail and could be daunting for the developers. However this game is just beautiful pixel art throughout the whole game, never getting repetitive or unfulfilling.  The game takes the shoot-em-up game, arcade style gameplay and mixes it with metoridvania free-roaming and item-gathering concepts to pimp up the Metal Slug-like gameplay to a more modernized version.   With hundreds of mission, carried out on several map levels, with endless of materials, gadgets, tech, armor and weapons to build and customize this game has shown us what the shoot-em-up genre will look like in the future. With all its content and lots of hard to catch achievements, this game will keep you coming back for more, for a very long time. I could not recommend this enough.  One note: Gamepad over Keyboard, any day.

As someone who's first platform was a original NES I found Mercenary Kings to be an excellent experience. I think the experience is a little Contra, a little River city Ransom, and a great deal of fun. It's nice to see that mercenary Kings supports multi player as well, my friends and I liek to try to race eachother to the objectives and treat each level like a speed run. The gun customization is satisfying especially for a 2D side scroller experience. I recommend hooking up a controller and playing this one on your TV for a great old school gaming expereince.
10/10 game of the year especially for recording with a friend XD
I absolutely love the characters and writing, but the gameplay paled for me after a while. Nevertheless, a very good game. Probably a lot more fun if you play with your friends.

first off this isn't metal slug, you rescue hostages and shoot stuff but thats about the only slimier thing. think of it more like a mega man mixed with monster hunter or something.   it is a fun co-op game. I love this game, but I think its an acquired taste.   you are given missions and side quest through out the game and when you complete it you receive gun parts to upgrade your gun in anyway you want, some people may find upgrading takes to long or is too grindy or something but i think its really cool and really enjoy it. as I said earlier I think its an acquired taste which I happen to love.  im also a sucker for the beautiful sprite design

You can make a 30 round shotgun. 10/10

To describe this game it's like Megaman, Contra, and River City Ransom had a baby and it was called Mercenary Kings. The game is difficult but fun. Side scrolling shooter with some rpg elements to it.

The movement and gunplay kills it for me. Went in expected fast moving action like metal slug but the slowpaced duck n shoot at every respawning enemy is just too much. take in mind that this is for solo play and only a few hours in but I'm already done.  With the camera killing me when going into a new screen cuze the camera follows you 15 seconds later while you are getting killed in the next screen. Not being able to change direction and doing an action at the same time, actions not stacking, relying on healthkits,shorter cqc range than the enemys (and can't move while using melee(so far)),Gears of war reload, timed missions.  Just feels like a sluggish metal slug with reload and resource farming, wich as i can tell so far don't do much gameplay change in the form of weapon crafting.   Well take a look at some of the more detailed reviews here and judge if you might like it. For me it's just lords of the fallen of metal slug but with wonkier controls.

Wanted to love it.  ...reloading...  The artwork is fantastic.  ...reloading...  The music is excellent.  ...reloading...    The gameplay, however  ...reloading...  is very  ...reloading...  slow. You will not run  ...reloading...  but you will gun  ...reloading...  then wait for the enemy to leave cover  ...reloading...  rinse and repeat  ...reloading...  and then do this for every  ...reloading...  single  ...reloading...  enemy. Oh yeah,  ...reloading...  you'll have to reload your gun once in a while.

This game is SO GOOD. It is like that cool game you heard about but never played. Like you cousin told you about the NES Metal Gear's plot, and you thought it would play like Contra. You also made it look cooler than it ever would on the NES. You made the perfect game a violent 11 year old would want to play in the 90's. Not one a violent 11 year old would make, but one they would play. This game is pretty polished, even though it has a little to much grinding. Also this game really is not like Metal Slug at all, it's like Contra. Sure the art style and sprites are similar, but the game play is more like Contra with slower (not slow) gameplay than Metal Slug. Also despite all the different levels, you will play the same levels with the same robots, and the same backgrounds over and over again. This makes the game loses a lot of its luster long before you can actually finish the game. Some of the ideas are interesting, the hunting, the upgrades to the guns, and the supporting characters. These all have flaws though. The hunting is repetative and gives few real rewards. The upgrades are confusing, with some bullets not working after you change one part of you gun. The supporting charaters are basically just fun one-liner machines, and while I like them they should have more lines, or somethings. Currently they just feel very repetative. That really is the main flaw of the game, how repetative it is. It should have had a few things cut, or more levels and enemies. It should provide hours of fun though.
Megaman + Contra + Scott Pilgrim + Metal Slug = Kickass (y)

Great art style and animation, fun and challenging game play, tons of customizations and resource gathering. It's very similar to metal slug esthetically and thematically, but the gameplay is pretty different in my opinion. mercenary kings is a much slower game and far less arcade-like, but you have more control over the character and more exploration, crafting, side missions, etc.  I think the control scheme could've been better though, and the game can sometimes get a bit grindy and repetitive.
It's cool to add new elements to a Shoot 'em up. But if the gameplay is not enjoyable enough, that won't save it.

Great game! First of all I have'nt played metal slug 'don't scream at me' but I can still relate this game to monster hunter which I have played. The game has amazing audio and the art style is great. I never say 'this music again' or 'that drone is so annoying'. The concept is nice but the story is meh. You go on missions with various objectives which sometimes can be unclear but don't give up. As you complete missions you advance on to new tiers that unlock new gun parts, knives, and progress you through the story. The best part is creating your own weapons. The wepon parts are divided into 6 parts, reciever, stock, barrel, magazine, sight, and ammo. Also there are different types of weapons like smgs, shotguns, snipers, magnums, and so on and so forth. You can mix and match or you can make a 100% shotgun to craft unique ammo only for shotguns. If you get 100% or over on a weapon type you can craft new ammo for it. And multiplayer too! There is 4 player co-op and it is a ton more fun with friends. Sometimes this game can get rather boring though, as many of the missions are rince and repeat but it keeps me going because I am always looking to improve my gear and unlocking new areas. Over all this game is great and highly recommend this game to anyone who likes platformers. 7/10
Best game to play with friends, and remmember the good old days spending hours on Metal Slug. If you wondering about a online, local co-op buy it, and enjoy.

Basically it's Metal Slug, but instead of jumping tanks there are levels with free exploration and fully customizable guns. Most important thing - they didn't ♥♥♥♥ up the controls which is so rare these days in platform shooters.

Mercenary Kings is a Metal Slug-like with material collection, equipment enhancements, and more specific mission goals other than simply reaching the end of a level and killing a big thing.  Once you get past the issue of setting up a proper controller - which can currently be done by remapping the 360 controller to whatever controller you use in Steam's Big Picture Mode then playing the game in that mode, the game feels very finessed in terms of fine character control and movement becomes fairly fluid.  The graphics are charming, the gameplay is generally fun, though sometimes it can be a little grindy looking for lots of a somewhat rare item to complete your equipment collections.  Overall this game is badass and very much worth the cost. We give this game a FIVE... ...out of five.
If you are thinking 'hey! That looks a little bit like a Metal Slug game!' - stop right there. The controls are  way  to clunky. It feels awful to traverse the levels.

Do you like everything everything about Monster Hunter except for the monsters, aesthetics & actual gameplay? You material gather to make gear like in Monster Hunter and HQ functions a lot like a town in the Monster Hunter series. As for the gameplay & aesthetics, the game is much closer to Metal Slug.  As strange as that sounds, these two clashing things mesh surprisingly well.

'What if you combined Scott Pilgrim with Metal Slug?' THIS GAME.
MARVELOUS. If you like arcade games like Metal slug, this is a must play.
Love this game. It is a combination of River City Ransom, Scott Pilgram vs the World, and Castle Crashers. Lots of weapon combonations to build and fun collection of items to find.
I bought 4-pack expecting co-op metalslug experience. But it turned out to be a repetitive, grind heavy game.

I loved this game! My wife and I played it regularly, and it was a blast! I hope they come out with a DLC/expansion.  If you liked metal slug, you'll like this game! The only annoying drawback to this game, is when you're doing local co-op, it splits the screen in a way that makes i very hard to see much of anything.
Build a machine gun that shoots flaming armor-peircing homing rockets and fight giant robots with it. Would Recommend

Nice game for online co op platformer.

Things I enjoyed: Artwork is fantastic (If you're into pixel graphics), music was engaging, and the bosses were pretty cool.  The knife mechanics are interesting, the ability to deflect bullets with your knife certainly makes the game easier. I enjoyed the different load outs I could make with a gun, and the different ammunitions associated with them. I think I'll always love hot hearts.  Definitely not Metal Slug, though.   Things I didn't enjoy: wanting to build a particular gun, only to realize I need to craft it using materials I have to keep finding throughout the game. In that sense, the grinding gets pretty boring. However, the use of achievements (like speed running the levels) make the grinding arbitrarily less annoying.  Personally, the use of a good gun renders the knife not very useful in situations.
Playing 30 Hours. Game Still interesting to play. Newer and newer upgrades makes game interesting. Best expirience from coop game .

Level design is terrible. The game's initial marketing is a bit misleading. ITS BORING. Look this is a try before you buy . The game looks good and I gave it an honest chance, but dear god is it a slog.
Seriously, what kind of keyboard control is this, mapping reload to [space]?
It's like Metal Slug without being Metal Slug with graphics by the dude who did Scoot Pilgrim. Yeah. That guy.

A fun romp through side-scrolling shooty action. The game plays very similarly to Metal Slug and games of that nature but with a bit more forgiveness. Gameplay's pretty standard and fun without too much innovation in terms of controls and whatnot but what keeps it interesting is the customizable weapons. You completely customize your loadout with 6 different weapon parts at any given time that have different stats that affect how your character plays. Will you take a handgun with only 2 parts and be super fast and agile but with limited firepower? Will you take a huge minigun with tons of ammo that pierces walls and completely destroys things before it gets on screen with the side-effects of moving slower than a slug in molasses? The entire game revolves around finding loot to craft new weapons and mods that change how you play your character. It works extremely well because of the focus that it has on variety and uniqueness to each weapon. It's not perfectly balanced yet but it's still in development so it's not an issue. An excellent game that really gets the visceral fun of just raining bullets down pat.
Fun oldschool platformer. ive enjoing it very much.

Fun game for the most part..  but I can't recommend because of a bug that stops you from playing the game at all.  Quite a few people have this issue with no way to fix it: Getting stuck on a black screen at start up or at the start of a mission or the end of a mission. At that point the game must be forced off.  Why is this crippling bug still around?

S'pretty fun for a while, but after a point the grind just got to be too much for me. I don't mind grinding, and actually enjoy it in a lot of games, but make grinding faster, more convenient, easier, and fun. Not slow, hard, boring, tedious and mind numbingly repetitive. I'm going to give this a no, but if I could I would simply give this a neutral vote or both, and if you can stand the grind then it's quite a lot of fun I feel, and would highly recommend it to those with sufficient patience to enjoy this game. I'm only giving this a no cause I personally couldn't stand the grinding. Honestly, my biggest problem with this game is that some materials are just way too hard to get in any kind of significant quantities. To get around this problem I suggest having higher tier enemies drop rarer materials instead of the common materials I already have literally hundreds of that all the lower tier enemies already drop. Also, the netcode could use improvement. At the moment it's kinda not very good.

Think Metal Slug, but annoying.  The essential is here but a lot of problems become obvious very quickly : Every enemy you kill respawns as soon as his corpse gets off screen ; The controls are not on point, there's always a delay between the press of a button and the action, cant shoot up while moving... ; Missions of a same rank all take place on the same map, gets repetitive real fast.  So there is still some fun to be had if you really enjoy the genre but a simple question comes up : Why play this when there is so much better ? And I don't see an answer to this one...

The only thing good about this game is the art.    Boring repetitive game play traversing the same map over and over for multiple missions killing the same enemies that reappear in the same spots. A crafting system that doesn't give much of an opportunity to experiment or preview weapon builds before spending your resources and too many stats to compare, very little incentive to really use different types of weapons or ammunition when caustic bullets pretty much handle everything. Reload mechanic is frustrating and disrupts the flow of the game, game does not pause when your viewing the map leaving you vulnerable to the reappearing enemies that may lurk off screen. Retrieving items from your backpack is slow and also disrupts game play you should really be able to toggle through items with a single button click rather than having to hold down a button then navigating a menu and then select your item, you also have go through your backpack to get the walkie talkie out just to call someone so you can leave a mission so many clicks for such a simple thing.   I wanted to like this game but I just couldn't get over the frustrating gameplay mechanics. The comparisons to Metal Slug make no sense this is nothing like Metal Slug not even close, If you wanna play a fast pace action platformer play Metal Slug if you want something slow, repetitive, and grindy play this game.
good luck trying to play this game on a keyboard. the defauly key bindings make it as impossible as possible

This game is great. Reminds me of the good old times of Mega Man and Contra. The music, the graphic, everything is very cool for an old gamer, but even new ones could appreciate it. Also the cooperative mode and the weapon and character custumization and upgrade make it a good choice.  Reccomended.

Think of this game as Metal Slug, but MUCH deeper. It's got a quest system with goals for every mission you do, including secret goals. You've got an absolute ♥♥♥♥-ton of things to buy to upgrade your character. You've got multiple different parts for your gun to interchange. Stuff like a barrel, magazine, stock, etc. You can have anything from a lightning sniper rifle to a fire submachine gun and everything in between, even being able to tweak how many bullets and your overall damage. You've got a knife that you can also have many different versions of. Useable items like first-aid kits, grenades, c4 to open some doors.  If you're a person who wants to get everything, buckle up. It's going to take you an awful long time to afford everything. Every mission is timed, which is a bit annoying at first. Especially when you haven't had a chance to familiarize yourself with a particular map. It's probably the biggest drawback to the game if you don't like being rushed. You'll normally have plenty of time, but some missions don't give you much room to breathe.  Luckily, there's co-op to help you through some of the tougher missions. You and up to 3 other people can join in the fun. Tons of bosses, tons of quests, tons of guns. It's how Metal Slug should've been designed in the first place.
Love this game, I only hope there's some sort of plans for dlc, it would make a world of a difference

The controles take awhile to get use to. J, K, and L wouldn't be my first choices for keys, but after a'lil play time, they become a cozy home for your finger tips. I'm rockin and rollin through levels with my guns, poppin fools left and right!
You love Metal Slug? You gotta try THIS GAME!

This is a hard one to describe. There are many complaints, but most of those complaints are about people thinking it's going to be similar to Metal Slug, which it's not. It takes inspiration from games like Monster Hunter and Megaman. And the reason I say a game like Monster Hunter is because the crafting system and online missions (Quests) are similar to Monster Hunter's. You have your sub missions and main missions, you must complete all the main missions to unlock your boss mission, or in Monster Hunter your 'Urgent Quest,' to move on to your next rank or 'Hunter Rank.'   As for Megaman, the game's enemies and precise shooting mechanics are very similar to the Megaman franchise. So close infact some enemies have the same gameplay mechanics, examples are the Floor Spiders acting the like Springers, and Riot Shields acting like the Sniper Joes from Megaman.   Since Monster Hunter and Megaman are two of my favorite videogame franchises of all time, I love this game, but I understand how some people might go into this game expecting a Metal Slug type game. If that's the case, Metal Slug 3 and X are available on Steam, which I highly recommend as well.

But if you still want to try it and will take it as Metal Slug clone... Let's just say: 'Hope is the first step on the road to disappointment.'   Seriously, we do need a 'mix' option for reviews.

Merc Kings has a great art style as you can see and that can go a long way if you like it. I find it to be fun despite a little repeatativeness. You find yourself going to the same areas several times on different missions. I understand it adds some replay value but it can feel redundant. The gameplay, in general, is fun. Obviously there's numberous weapon upgrades and combinations, it's really interesting to mess around and tweak with those. What a lot of reviewers don't mention is that there are other mods like armor, health, melee knife, and bullet mods. You collect material found on missions for all these upgrades. I didn't find myself struggling too much to save up for the mods I wanted. Yes there's fetch missions but they are purely optional and usually offer big material bonuses.  Pros -Fun quirky graphic/art style -co-op online and local -upgrades! -full controller support -moderate difficulty  Cons -several missions repeat map areas  -fetch missions -zomg its not metal slug!! (jk)
super fun game with a lot of difrent weapon options might be anoying t the beginning when you dont have any good weapons but later on it becomes a addictivly good platform shooter / colector game

Disclaimer: I might not 'get' the game.  This game is hard to love, it's one of those games that has the promise of combining all the best parts of old skool games. I'm sure at some level this was what the developers are going for, a nostalgic game they would've liked to see, indisriminately taking the things we all loved about platformers etc.  Sadly, it's more like the best and the absolute worst aspects of games from the 8bit and 16bit era. It's as if the developers have learned absolutely nothing from modern game design. This game is extremely frustrating, and most of it comes down to horrible design and core mechanics.   The biggest issue I have apart from the bad overall design, is that while the developers have tried to combine many different elements from successful games, the overall experience is worse off than any of those individual games it tries to imitate.Some gameplay choices don't play well with each other and their attempt at syncretizing these becomes detrimental to the overall experience,  I tried playing this game with multiple friends, and it's hard for me to insist on it when it's obvious no one is enjoying a single second of it.  A real shame, but the era for frustrating pieces of ♥♥♥♥ that you just love to hate are over.  However, if you're one of those people that is scourging through the reviews to find reassuring confirmation of why you'd love this game, and are desperate for the possible potential it might have I would in fact recommend this game. You might not play it for very long, but it does have an allure of enjoyment, one that it doesn't really deliver on, but afterall, like the developers, sometimes we like the idea of something over the actual thing itself.

Does blasting an army of bad guys to smithereens Metal Slug-style sound like your idea of a good time? How about doing it with your own custom-made weapon using whatever mishmash of parts you can think of? If any of that appeals to you, then this is absolutely worth a shot.  Paul Robertson's handmade sprites and backdrops do a lot to give the experience that retro/fake-retro charm without coming across as just pixelated for the sake of it. The soundtrack's combination of metal and chiptune-like tones calls to mind things like Virt's compositions for Contra 4 and DuckTales Remastered.  Once you get some momentum going, it's lots of fun crafting gun parts, bionic mods and even substitutes for your trusty knife, to put together your own personal loadout and see how it performs.  There's a couple hitches though. To me at least, the system of equipment weighing you down seems out of place, and the Monster Hunter-type layout of missions giving you different objectives in the same areas means it can get kind of repetitive, especially if there's a gun part or something you REALLY want to get the materials for.  Trifles aside, it's a fine example of mashing together run-and-gun violence and strategic weapon crafting.

Mercenary Kings is a game by Tribute, mixing 2D run&gun gameplay with a crafting system similar to the Monster Hunter series. You play as one of two Kings-mercenaries trying to put an end to the nefarious Claw by completing a large amount of different missions like gathering missions, hostage rescues and elimination missions. During these missions, you gather money and materials, which can be used to craft new powerful weapons to even your odds against the overwhelming mass of Claw forces. While Mercenary Kings sound awesome, it turned into a mediocre/bad one due to many, many questionable game design decisions. Sigh. It's Scott Pilgrim all over again.    The Good   - As expected of Paul Robertson, the Pixel Art is awesome. The terrain looks great and the characters are perfectly animated. - Great character designs. - The soundtrack fits the game very well. - On- & offline co-op. - Weapons crafting is well done and yields some really cool weapons.    The Bad   - Not all weapon parts can be combined. - Heavy weapons parts will slow your character down. - 4 player co-op and only 2 playable characters. Because nothing says immersion more than fighting alongside your unique character's color-swapped clone. - There's a small delay when you jump, making jumps feel odd. - Touching the enemy hurts you and knocks you back. Now there's an old video game sin that should've been buried in the New Mexican desert a long time ago. While it does make sense with some enemies (running into a knife or an industrial drill is not a good health plan), this seems particularly silly considering the fact that most enemies do have an attack animation. - Critters count as enemies, meaning that touching a critter hurts your character as well. So yes, your mandrake-powered mercenaries can potentially be killed by a bunny. And there's not even a holy grenade to even the odds. - Speaking of old video game sins that should've been buried, ♥♥♥ soon as the enemy spawn point is off-screen, the enemy will respawn. It's like you've never been there at all! - Enemies with full frontal immunity; that is a full frontal I do not like. Whereas shielded enemies in Metal Slug would drop the shield if it took too much damage, the enemies in Mercenary Kings are pretty much invulnerable as long as the shield's up. So, as mentioned above, you can't just move past them and jumping over them is rarely an option too, meaning you'll have to wait until the expose their weak spot to attack them. And boy, they're not in a hurry to drop their defenses. - Weapons need to be reloaded. Because why slow down the game flow if it can be brought to a grinding stop instead? - No diagonal aiming. - No item quickslot. In order to use an item, you'll first have to equip it, then use it. This is not only annoying when you need to use an item quickly, it renders some items such as the riot shield useless, as it takes too long to use them. And on top of that, while you've equipped an item, you can't use your gun. - You can't buy a full stock of items, even if you can afford them. If I can carry 5 rations, why can I only buy 4?    The Ugly   - As all missions of a chapter take place in the same level, you'll see the same levels over and over again. - EVERY mission has a time limit, even gathering missions that require random loot from enemies. Why do I need a time limit when gathering materials to fix the tents? Do my oh so powerful mercenaries catch the sniffles if I don't gather them on time? - Do you like time limits? Then you'll love boss fights, 'cause those are timed too! As soon as the boss timer runs out, the boss will run away. Get this: the big guy's got a knife your size (it's literally as big as your character) and he runs away few minutes into the fight. And although the boss escapes through a huge cave, you can't follow him. No, you'll have to fight your way through the level again to continue fighting that big chicken. And of course, no backtracking experience would've been complete without a full enemy respawn! - Adding insult to injury, the boss timer starts running again as soon as the boss makes his appearance again. So, if you take to much time reaching the new boss area, the bugger's gone to another place. - Be on you guard when reaching a new boss area. The boss can attack you before you even entered the area.    Verdict    I really wanted to like this game, but the many, many flaws just kill it for me. Sigh. I should stop being a sucker for Paul Robertson's artwork. If you're looking for fast-paced run&gun action like Metal Slug, don't buy this game. Go buy Metal Slug 3 instead. If you don''t mind the slower pace and the flaws mentioned above, you might want to take a look at it. Weapon crafting's good fun, and so's co-op run&gun games.

Mercenary Kings is a game that doesn't understand itself, leading to many missed opportunities. Gun customization is fun, and it controls and plays very well, sadly level and enemy design are not up to snuff to make it all come together.  The source inspiration for a title like this seems obvious to most players, but I don't know if the developers really got into what made those games work. The graphics are great, building guns is fun and shooting enemies is entertaining. The biggest complaint you'll see for Mercenary Kings is that it is too easy. And this is true. The enemies are placed in ways that make them easy to dispatch, and the ones that shoot don't do it enough to be threatening. It's rare to have even two projectiles on the screen at a time, let alone enemies. Even with that handicap on their part, your character can take multiple hits AND increase their health later on. Because of this, the most dangerous parts of the game are the very rare pitfalls that actually kill you. The game ramps up a bit towards the end, but considering how comotose the first five ranks are its just a little too late.  Now, I put this as not recommended but that's only because there is no 'on the fence' option. On one hand the game is entertaining enough and has an enjoyable art style, and on the other I can't lie and tell you this is a game you are going to remember. I would consider this a casual side-scroller, and honestly that isn't a game I would recommend. If you have no hands you may find this game challenging but this is something you play when an alternative would be to take a nap.

I'm going to try very hard to avoid saying 'this is like X meets Y' because those types of comparisons kind of annoy me. With that in mind, here goes:  This game is side-scrolling run-and-gun at its very finest. Tight controls meet challenging level design and enemies that aren't (always) simply mooks that charge at you full speed. There's a very interesting crafting system that allows you to mix and match weapon components (receiver, magazine, etc.) to make a gun to suit your desired method of mayhem. This same system also has in place 'implants' which confer bonuses (and disadvantages too!)  My favorite part of the game, however, is that it takes item weight into account. Weapon parts, implants, consumables you carry to battle,  everything  has weight and weight affects your movement speed. This creates an interesting strategic balance: do you bring the massive crush-everything loadout, sacrificing speed in the quest for power? Do you streamline to what you think you need and nothing else, trusting in agility and a quick trigger finger to win through? Or is your path to victory somewhere in the middle? This game doesn't judge, instead setting the options before you and letting you decide how best to assault its varying missions.  And oh, the missions! Not content with simple 'run to the right and kill it if it moves' gameplay, the game will present you with sections of a whole area that will become familiar over time, but ask different things of you each visit. Sometimes you'll be gathering items, other times it's search and destroy, still others your task is to seek out and rescue a captive (or more than one!) The variety of tasks you take on keeps the game from feeling repetitive, instead rewarding thorough exploration and familiarization with each map with secret passages and hidden treasures, not to mention helping to get quick times if (when) you go for speed-runs.  TL;DR = This game is a lot of awesome. If you like run-and-gun sidescrollers and you like customization, it's amazing.

A fun 2D platformer/shooter type deal with an amazing visual theme, good controls, and a decent amount of content.  Movement, controls, and weight mechanic are all well done and made this game a joy to play. The levels are full of impressively detailed pixel art animations which match the story to give the game a lot of character. The majority of the enemies and bosses are fun to fight, and learning the sprawling level layouts is rewarding. After you beat the game speedrunning levels adds a lot of content and is thankfully pretty achievable, dependant more on knowing map layouts and enemy patterns than raw skill. The multiplayer is also really nice, but due to random matching you can get groups of folks who are very different skill/progress levels, which sometimes doesn't work out so well.  The gun crafting system is interesting and allows one to customize for their personal playstyle, but there are some combinations which are just better than most others and so are more widely used. Farming for materials shouldn't be much of an issue during the game, but the rarer end game achievements (craftsmanship, etc.) will definitely require a bit of farming. Default keyboard controls are pretty weird, but I got used to it and now it feels natural. Can be remapped if desired anyway.  Overall a really well made game, certainly worth a try.

It certainly looks cool enough (metal slug, anyone?), but just doesn't hold up if you keep playing it.  The start is pretty modest. You get some perhaps even above average plot about rescueing a scientist, lots of colorful characters and nice looking animations. The game itself starts out nicely as well. There are crafting materials to gather, people to rescue who can upgrade your stuff and even the reload mechanic is pretty interesting...  ...but then it starts to show that the next missions take place on the same map, using the same enemies on the same locations. Worse: since gathering missions sort of have you search the entire place, going back to that very same map for a different item isn't just not fun but downright tedious. I can but assume there actually ARE more than two maps, but it really doesn't look that way. The enemies respawn a bit too fast as well, btw. As in: way too fast. Then I haven't even talked about locations where you can find C4 to blow up a door which the game practically assumes you know by heart (which, to be fair, is actually the case, since you'll be backtracking so often).  So...since I got it in a humble bundle, I can't really complain. But I won't be playing it further. And can't think of anyone who would enjoy playing through to the end. It looks like it has many levels (about ten in the easiest rank, and there are quite some further ranks), but I sort of pity completionists here...
